section.name: NURSING OF THE CHILDBEARING FAMILY: THEORY/CLINICAL

comments:
Course content is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the
family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The
student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and
their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or
family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during
childbearing. Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of
the theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical
experiences in a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the
Instructional Technology Center. The students care for the families with both simple and
complex needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student
assists in managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum,
and neonatal periods.
Overall, students found this course to be “well-organized,” but they also felt it
was “alot of material to cover in such a short span of time.” Many students felt that there
was an “excessively heavy workload,” but they praised the “interesting course material,”
and called it “the best course I’ve ever taken.”
Students found Professor Stern “engaging” and said that “the time went by really
quickly,” and they claimed that the classwork was all “relevant to work” and
stimulating.”
Students expressed that Stern had an “excessively heavy workload,” and several
“felt like I had to self teach a lot.” But, they lauded her “fair grading” and say it as an
interesting intro level nursing course.

section.name: NURSING OF THE CHILDBEARING FAMILY: THEORY/CLINICAL

comments:
Course content is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the
family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The
student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and
their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or
family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during
childbearing. Using the nursing process, nursing strategies are developed for maintaining
family members individually, for promoting optimal physiological and psychological
functioning, and enhancing strengths within the family members and within the family
unit. Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of the
theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical experiences in
a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the Instructional
Technology Center (ITC). The student cares for families with both simple and complex
needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student assists in
managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum, and
neonatal periods.
Students in general found the material "interesting," "unusual," and "engaging,"
but felt the class could be structured better. Students felt that the non-lecture components
were relevant and provided real-world applications of the material.
The course is co-taught by Professors Guidera and Stern. Students felt that their
instructors were "approachable" and passionate about the material. However, several
students felt that there were grading inconsistencies among the professors and lab
instructors.
Students felt that the course moved quickly and required a lot of work,
particularly the dense readings. Some students also remarked on the difficulty of the tests.
However, students generally responded positively about the amount they learned in the
course.

Course content is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the
family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The
student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and
their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or
family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during
childbearing. Using the nursing process, nursing strategies are developed for maintaining
family members individually, for promoting optimal physiological and psychological
functioning, and enhancing strengths within the family members and within the family
unit. Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of the
theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical experiences in
a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the Instructional
Technology Center (ITC). The student cares for families with both simple and complex
needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student assists in
managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum, and
neonatal periods.
Many students found this to be a stressful course. Lab hours were insufficient,
workload was high, and open lab was run at the same time as sim lab, which several
students found distracting. Most students did see potential value in this course but
thought it requires much redesigning.
Some students complained that the lab instructors gave mixed instructions, and
that the ratio of students to instructors was unfavorable; however, others praised
individual instructors.
Grading was a source of anxiety for students in this course, as many felt
unprepared for the assessments due to the vague instruction and poorly chosen readings.
